title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a license, or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willful violations of the chapter or regulations. This includes penalties for transferring armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a license, impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willful violations, including transferring armor-piercing ammunition. Additionally, the Secretary can compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any violations. The Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of regulations. Any actions taken by the Secretary can be reviewed only as provided in subsection (f) regarding applicants and licensees' rights. The Secretary's actions can be reviewed only as outlined in subsection (f) regarding applicants and licensees' rights. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or imposes a civil penalty, written notice must be provided stating the specific grounds for the decision. The Secretary must provide written notice of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment to the affected party, stating specific grounds and giving notice before the effective date of revocation or suspension. An appeal process with a hearing is available if the Secretary denies an application. The Secretary must provide written notice of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment to the affected party before the effective date. An appeal process with a hearing is available upon request for review. Upon request, the Secretary shall hold a hearing to review denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment of a license. If the decision is not reversed after the hearing, an appeal process is available. The Secretary shall hold a hearing at a convenient location for the aggrieved party. If the decision is not reversed, the Secretary must provide notice of the decision and allow a 60-day appeal period. The Secretary may deny, revoke, or suspend a license and assess a civil penalty. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court within 60 days of receiving notice of the decision. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court for judicial review within 60 days of receiving notice of the decision. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court for judicial review within 60 days of receiving notice of the decision. In the judicial proceeding, the court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. In the judicial proceeding, the court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. If the court finds that the Secretary was not authorized to make the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment, the court will order the Secretary to take action. In a judicial proceeding, the court may consider evidence submitted by parties. If the court determines the Secretary's actions were unauthorized, they will order necessary compliance. The court may order necessary compliance with its judgment if the Secretary suspends or revokes a license or assesses a civil penalty. The effective date of the revocation, suspension, or assessment can be stayed pending an appeal. Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction, changing the wording from "until any conviction pursuant to the indictment becomes final" to "until the date of any conviction pursuant to the indictment".
